Amazon Macy is an AI powered security
service that helps you prevent data loss
by automatically discovering classifying
and protecting sensitive data stored in
AWS Macy uses machine learning to
recognize sensitive data such as
personally identifiable information or
intellectual property it assigns a
business value and provides visibility
into where this data is stored and how
it is being - used in your organization
Macy continuously monitors data access
for anomalies and delivers alerts when
it detects a risk of unauthorized access
or inadvertent data leaks you can use
Macy to protect against security threats
by continuously monitoring your data and
account credentials Macy gives you an
automated and low touch way to discover
and classify your business data when
alerts are generated you can use Macy
for incident response using automation
based on cloud watch events to swiftly
take action to protect your data Macy
uses machine learning to better
understand where your sensitive
information is located and how it's
typically accessed including user
authentication locations and times of
access today Macy is available to
protect data stored in Amazon s3 with
additional support for more AWS services
coming later Macy first creates a
baseline and then actively monitors for
anomalies that indicate risks and/or
suspicious behavior such as large
quantities of source code being
downloaded credentials being stored in
an unsecured manner or sensitive data
that is configured to be externally
accessible with a Macy console your most
important information is front and
center with detailed alerts and

issues Macy also gives you the ability
to easily define and
mise automated remediation actions such

baseline more specifically Macy
continuously monitors activity within
your AWS infrastructure and builds a

for deviation from that normal baseline
and when such activity is detected it
generates automate automatic predictive

in a single day might trigger an alert
if that user typically only downloads
one or two s3 objects over the course of

there is not enough data generated for a

baseline it does this by using peer
group analysis for example each user is
modeled across several features that are

the numbers of spreadsheets that are
viewed in a day users are then grouped
by similar feature profiles which is
another term for a peer group for
example users with a high number of
spreadsheets viewed in a day might be

people who view a large amount of
documents Macy then detects when a
user's act
Falls above the predicted range of

in this example the final action is to
